Introduction

Osteoarthritis (OA) is a very common musculoskeletal disorder characterized by progressive loss of articular cartilage, alterations in subchondral bone, and osteophyte formation.  It is a leading cause of chronic pain and disability worldwide, predominantly affecting the knees, hips, hands, and spine.

Pathophysiology



The etiology of OA is multifactorial, with excessive biomechanical stress and relative overactivity of intraarticular metalloproteases as the major contributors to cartilage destruction.  As OA progresses, the collagen and proteoglycan components of articular cartilage are degraded and replaced by increased water content.  In advanced OA, apoptosis of chondrocytes can lead to fragility of the articular cartilage, resulting in fragmentation of the cartilage, exposure of subchondral bone (

figure 1
), and formation of loose bodies and subchondral cysts in the underlying bone.



Although a number of proinflammatory mediators (eg, IL-6, macrophage chemotactic protein-1) have been linked to OA, overt signs of synovitis (eg, redness, warmth) are less prominent than in classic inflammatory arthritic disorders (eg, gout).  Effusions, if present, are typically small.

Risk factors



  • Age:  Prevalence increases with age.
  • Obesity:  Causes excessive mechanical loading on weight-bearing joints.
  • Joint injury or trauma:  Increases the risk of OA (ie, post-traumatic OA).
  • Genetic factors:  Family history predisposes individuals to OA.
  • Occupation:  Jobs involving repetitive joint movements or heavy lifting may aggravate symptoms.
  • Joint malalignment:  Abnormal joint mechanics generate pathologic forces on articular cartilage.

Pathology



Gross inspection of involved joints shows focal or diffuse erosion of articular cartilage, often with eburnation (ie, sclerotic, "polished" appearance) of subchondral bone.  Bony osteophytes may be seen at joint margins.



Histologically, OA is characterized by surface fibrillation and erosion of articular cartilage.  Chondrocytes may be diminished or absent due to apoptosis.  Synovium may show hypertrophy, hypervascularity, and villous changes.  A lymphocytic synovial infiltrate may be seen in some specimens.

Clinical presentation



OA manifests with joint pain, stiffness, periarticular bony enlargement, and decreased range of motion.  In the absence of trauma, which can accelerate development of OA, symptoms are typically chronic and insidious.  Common patterns of OA include the following:



  • Knee:  Anterior or medial knee pain is aggravated by weight-bearing activities, and stiffness occurs after periods of inactivity.  Joint swelling and crepitus may also be present.
  • Hip:  Pain in the groin, buttock, or thigh region is characteristic and often worsens with prolonged standing or walking.  Patients may exhibit limited hip range of motion and altered gait.
  • Hand: Patients may experience pain, stiffness, and reduced grip strength, affecting fine motor tasks.  Involvement of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints is associated with Heberden nodes (ie, periarticular bony enlargements at the DIP joint); involvement of the proximal interphalangeal joints is associated with Bouchard nodes (
    image 1
    ).  The 1st carpometacarpal joint is also a common site, particularly in postmenopausal women.
  • Spine:  OA can involve the facet joints and intervertebral discs.  Lumbar and cervical regions are most commonly affected.  Symptoms include chronic (but often intermittent) pain and reduced range of motion.  Osteophyte formation and disc degeneration can lead to spinal stenosis (
    figure 2
    ) and radiculopathy.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of OA is based primarily on clinical evaluation, including history and physical examination findings.  Laboratory tests, such as inflammatory markers (eg, C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate) are typically normal and ordered primarily to rule out other inflammatory conditions.  X-rays are the initial imaging modality of choice, demonstrating characteristic joint changes such as osteophytes, joint space narrowing (

image 2
), and subchondral sclerosis (
image 3
).  MRI and CT scans are not usually necessary but may provide additional information on complex joint pathology or for surgical planning.

Differential diagnosis



  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  Typically affects the small joints of the hands (especially metacarpophalangeal joints) and wrists.  RA causes inflammatory synovitis, manifesting as doughy swelling at the joint with prolonged morning stiffness (eg, >30 minutes), whereas hand OA more often affects the interphalangeal joints and is associated with hard/bony swelling and only brief or no stiffness.  Inflammatory markers, serologic studies (eg, rheumatoid factor, cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies), and x-ray can make the definitive distinction.
  • Spondyloarthropathies (eg, ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis):  Can cause peripheral arthritis resembling OA but often also involve the spine and sacroiliac joints; they are frequently associated with enthesitis (inflammation at tendon and ligament insertions) and extraarticular findings (eg, uveitis).  Pain is frequently worse with rest (eg, overnight) and associated with prolonged stiffness.  Spondyloarthopathies often begin in the second and third decades and are associated with HLA-B27 serotype.
  • Soft-tissue overuse syndromes:  Pain originating in periarticular soft tissues (eg, tendons, bursae); pain resembles that of OA and often occurs in association with OA imaging findings.  Focal tenderness in nonarticular structures and abnormal findings on specific evocative maneuvers may clarify the diagnosis.
  • Other disorders:  Chronic musculoskeletal pain commonly due to fibromyalgia and other myofascial pain disorders.  Hemochromatosis can cause chronic arthritis resembling OA but preferentially affects the wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints.  Avascular necrosis of the femoral head causes chronic hip pain and reduced range of motion; x-ray shows collapse of the articular surface of the femoral head.

Management



Management of OA involves a multimodal approach aimed at relieving symptoms, improving joint function, and minimizing disability.  A structured management plan typically includes the following components (

figure 3
):

Nonpharmacological interventions



  • Weight loss:  Encouraged for overweight or obese individuals to reduce mechanical stress on weight-bearing joints.
  • Exercise:  Combination of aerobic, strength, and flexibility exercises to improve joint stability, muscle strength, and range of motion.
  • Physical therapy:  To provide individualized exercise programs, manual therapy, and education on joint protection techniques.

Pharmacological therapy



  • Analgesics:  Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are first-line treatment for pain relief in most patients.  Major adverse effects include kidney injury and NSAID gastropathy (eg, gastric ulcer).  Acetaminophen can be considered for patients with contraindications to NSAIDs, but effectiveness is limited and may not outweigh adverse effects.
  • Topical agents:  Capsaicin cream or topical NSAIDs can be considered for localized pain relief in patients with involvement of only 1 or a few joints.
  • Intraarticular injections:  Corticosteroid injections provide short-term pain relief for symptomatic joints.  Hyaluronic acid injections (viscosupplementation) may be considered for knee OA, but evidence for effectiveness is mixed.

Joint replacement surgery



Total joint arthroplasty is indicated for patients with end-stage OA unresponsive to conservative measures that results in significant pain and functional impairment.  Use is predominantly limited to large joints (eg, knee, hip).

Assistive devices



Canes, braces, or orthotics may help reduce joint stress and improve mobility.

Prognosis



OA is a chronic, progressive condition.  Patients typically experience increasing loss of function and involvement of additional joints with aging.  Loss of mobility and chronic pain are common, although pain levels do not accelerate predictably or correlate consistently with severity of joint damage.

Summary



Osteoarthritis (OA) (

) is a common joint disease characterized by progressive cartilage loss and joint remodeling.  Age, obesity, joint injury, and genetic factors are among the key risk factors.  Diagnosis is based on clinical evaluation and imaging findings, with treatment aimed at pain relief and preserving joint function.  Despite its chronic nature, effective management can significantly improve outcomes and enhance quality of life.
